messageBody:
Kumar,

Mocking those getter methods might be overkill. Does the result of
your big method vary at all or is it dependent solely on the state of
the variables after initialization?

Michael Feathers

edu_kumar wrote:

>Hi all,
>
>I've been stuck with a problem, when i'm unit testing my code.
>
>My problem is that i've a really huge method,which calls several small
>methods ( methods so small, they're just getters for member
>variables), If i have to unit test this method, i've to make sure all
>the small methods that it subsequently invoke, work as they're
>expected. But all my member variables get initialized seperately in a
>different method which is of no relation with the BIG method I wanted
>to test in the first place.
>
>Can I test my method without worrying about the initialization of my
>object's data, by mocking the results of all my getter methods ?
>
>Ex:
>
>Class MyClass
>{
> private Object _member;
> public void initialize()
> {
> //huge initialization process, which initializes my member
>variables.
> _member = new Object();
> }
>
> public void myHugeMethod()
> {
> //.. my logic here.
> Object m = getMember();
> //... proceed with this value.
> }
>
> public Object getMember()
> {
> return this._member;
> }
>}
>
>Now, if I call 'myHugeMethod()' without calling 'initialize()' method,
>it always return NULL.
>
>All i wanted to do is to test 'myHugeMethod()', by mocking
>'getMember()' method and setting the result what i wanted.
>
>I tried using Jmock for creating mocks in my test case, but it fails
>because the mock object only knows what exactly I wanted to mock but
>nothing more than that. All my application logic is present in
>'MyClass' object not in its mock.
>
>How can I achieve this using Jmock ?
>
>FYI, I tried with a direct approach by extending 'MyClass' and
>overriding the 'getMember()' method in it. But I still feel there's a
>better way to do it.
>
>I'll be very thankful for any help in this regard..
>
>Thanks in advance,
>Sarat kumar.
>
>
>
>
